content.value: A language used to write programs or code; a set of instructions given to a computer to perform a particular task.
A high-level, object-oriented programming language designed for platform independence.
The Java program we write is known as source code (e.g., .java files), which our system cannot directly understand.

items: To overcome platform dependency, Java uses two key components: Compiler and JVM (Java Virtual Machine).
Compiler (javac) checks the syntax of the Java program and generates bytecode (or .class file).
JVM understands the bytecode and converts it into binary or machine-level language specific to the host system.
Write source code (.java file).
Compiler translates source code to bytecode (.class file).
JVM loads, verifies, and executes bytecode on any platform.

content.value: This 'write once, run anywhere' model makes Java portable across operating systems like Windows, Linux, and macOS.
javac tool that performs syntax checking and compiles human-readable Java source code into platform-independent bytecode.

items: Detects syntax errors before runtime.
Generates intermediate bytecode (.class files).
Does not execute the code; only translates it.

content.value: An abstract computing machine that enables Java bytecode to run on any device with a JVM implementation.

items: Loads bytecode via Class Loader subsystem.
Verifies bytecode for security and correctness.
Executes bytecode using Interpreter and JIT Compiler.
Manages memory (heap, garbage collection), threads, and security.

content.value: Source Code (.java) -> Compiler (javac) -> Bytecode (.class) -> JVM -> Machine Code (Binary)
